Comment: As much as I shit on the DNC for being reactionary centrist hacks, this is actually a good move.  Post New Deal Democrats (from 76-present) neglected state legislature so badly. It allowed the gerrymandering to get worse and worse and this is the first of many steps to turning that page.  Democrats used to dominate state legislature. There's currently about 4,100 Republicans in state legislative seats to about 3,200 Democrats. Chip away in the state houses for the long term projects.  The GOP motivates their base across consistent ideological points with local flavor sprinkled on top. Democrats need to recapture the message that local government affects people the most, focus on statehouses and start peeling back control from the GOP.

Comment: It kind of sucks because there is no way red states will ever see past this. Everyone who votes in red states has a really comfortable life. So they feel like the Democrat‚Äôs social spending programs are a threat to their lives.¬†  I actually agree that there needs to be more outreach in red states. The Democrat voters there know they are outnumbered and they know they will lose the election. They‚Äôre tired of having to put up with Republican policies.¬†  But the thing is, Democrats are hemorrhaging in blue states. Trump made the widest gains in blue states. Republicans know that by pitting men against women, they can cause massive losses to Democrats in blue states because now you have 45% of the population debating whether Trump is a little better for them. And if you only get 25% to vote red, that 25% might convince their wives to vote red. California is 35% to 65% state where Dems are safe. But with this new agenda, you got 25% voting red reliably and that 25% brings in 15% with them, bringing the total to 40%. Then they can make further gains by pitching economic growth to the undecided female voters. Although that might be like 2 or 3%, this number can grow if you pass very restrictive abortion laws, but you let the blue states decide how to follow them. Then all of a sudden you get 1% more believing that maybe it‚Äôs not the end of the world if they have less rights, as long as they get to keep a comfortable lifestyle. And then you defund education, where women outnumber men, 55% up to 60% in some states. That means in 10 years, women will be more focused on nonpolitical agenda. And this is actually where the Republican Party excels because they go into small towns and sensationalize the violent crimes in the area and the people there have developed a belief that the violence is spilling over from a nearby Democrat-run city who can‚Äôt keep control. And violence is an issue that women care deeply about as it is harder for them to fight back (think Ana Kasparian). But the men are told that Liberal women are too naive about the real world. And they are also told that since they fight the wars, their vote should be stronger.¬†

Author: nerphurp

Comment: Agreed. The Democrats are facing a monumental task to undo 50 years of listlessness.  I read a good book last week called Chaotic Neutral by Ed Burmilla, an unabashed progressive, but talented political historian tracing the shift of the party from being a stalwart for the working class to being the baroque lifestyle branding it's become.  A large portion is focused on how Democrats dominated statehouses into the 90s and how the gerrymandering of 2000 and 2010 from state legislature slimmed down Democratic national chances to gain consistent majorities.  He also goes into the way that the Republican party is able to consistently message their party platform at the localest of local levels (think about insane school board members) all the way to the white house. And how Democrats haven't responded to this shift for 20 years and it detached people from the national party. I don't agree with all his points necessarily but overall I highly recommend it.
Author: Pike_Gordon
